questions.question: A 7-year-old child presents to the ER with rapidly progressing swelling under the jaw and difficulty breathing. On examination, there is bilateral submandibular swelling with elevation of the tongue, but no trismus or fluctuation. He reports recent dental pain in his lower molars. Which anatomical connection is primarily responsible for the rapid bilateral spread of this infection?

options.A: Between the submental and parapharyngeal spaces
options.B: Between the sublingual and retropharyngeal spaces
options.C: Between the submandibular and submental spaces
options.D: Between the submental and buccal spaces

questions.question: A 40-year-old female presents with bilateral submandibular swelling and difficulty swallowing. On examination the swelling is "woody-hard," and the patient exhibits trismus. A CECT scan confirms the presence of diffuse cellulitis without a well-formed abscess. Which of the following is the most critical initial step in managing this condition?

options.A: Administer intravenous corticosteroids to reduce inflammation
options.B: Perform an intraoral incision and drainage to relieve pressure
options.D: Conduct a repeat contrast-enhanced CT scan to monitor progression

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Initiate systemic broad-spectrum antibiotics immediately Explanation: In the absence of a well-formed abscess, the primary and critical initial management for Ludwig’s angina is to start systemic broad-spectrum antibiotics. This helps to address the mixed bacterial infection and prevent further progression. Ludwig’ angina Clinical Features General Symptoms: Severe difficulty swallowing ( odynophagia ) and varying degrees of trismus (difficulty opening the mouth). Symptoms depend on infection location and extent: Sublingual Space: Swelling in the floor of the mouth, pushing the tongue upward and backwards. Submandibular Region: Swelling and tenderness in the submandibular area, often described as " woody - hard ." Progression: The tongue can displace upward and backward, potentially obstructing the airway, with possible laryngeal edema. Diagnosis Clinical Evaluation: Assess symptoms, including swelling, tenderness, trismus, and airway compromise. Imaging Studies: Ultrasound: Identifies abscess presence and location. Contrast-enhanced CT Scan : Differentiates between abscess and cellulitis (Phlegmon), revealing infection extent. Treatment Systemic Antibiotics : Broad-spectrum antibiotics to target mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacteria. Incision and Drainage: Necessary if an abscess is present. (Option B ruled out) Intraoral Approach : For infections confined to the sublingual space. External Approach : For infections in the submandibular and submental spaces, involving a transverse incision along the mandible. Airway Management: Maintaining a patent airway is crucial; tracheostomy may be needed in severe cases. Complications Spread of Infection: May extend to the parapharyngeal and retropharyngeal spaces and potentially to the mediastinum, causing mediastinitis. Airway Obstruction Septicaemia Aspiration Pneumonia Administer intravenous corticosteroids to reduce inflammation (Option A): While corticosteroids may help with inflammation in some cases, they are not the primary treatment for Ludwig’s angina, especially when systemic antibiotics are urgently needed. Conduct a repeat contrast-enhanced CT scan to monitor progression (Option D): While monitoring is important, the immediate priority in managing Ludwig’s angina with diffuse cellulitis is to start systemic antibiotics rather than repeating imaging. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 8th Edition, Page 310, 311

questions.question: In the development of a pharyngeal pouch, which anatomical area is primarily affected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Killian’s dehiscence Explanation: Killian’s dehiscence is more prone to the formation of a pharyngeal pouch or Zenker's diverticulum due to increased pressure during swallowing, leading to the outpouching of mucosal tissue. Laimer's dehiscence: It is also present below Killian's dehiscence, but its position is in the midline below the cricopharyngeus Pharyngeal Pouch: Also called hypopharyngeal diverticulum or Zenker’s diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum. Usually seen after 60yrs of age. Pharyngeal mucosa herniates through Killian’s dehiscence. Killian’s dehiscence is a triangular area of muscular weakness located in the wall of the hypopharynx, specifically between the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus and the transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle. Pathophysiology: Due to spasm of cricopharyngeal sphincter, the pressure within the pharynx rises significantly during swallowing. This increased pressure forces the mucosal lining of the pharynx to herniate through the weak spot at Killian’s dehiscence. Herniation of pouch starts in midline behind the esophagus, and then comes to the left. Mouth of the sac is wider than the opening of the esophagus and food preferentially enters the sac.

questions.question: A 65-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, chronic bad breath, and a gurgling sound in his neck during swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Zenker's diverticulum Explanation: Zenker's Diverticulum: Outpouching of the pharyngeal mucosa through a weak area in the posterior pharyngeal wall (Killian's dehiscence). Clinical features: Dysphagia is the most prominent feature appears when the pouch gets filled with food and presses on the oesophagus. Gurgling sound produced on swallowing. Regurgitation at night of the undigested food, causing cough and aspiration pneumonia. Halitosis(Chronic bad breathe) Malnourished due to dysphagia. Associated hiatus hernia Rarely Cooma can develop in long-standing cases of pharyngeal pouch. Diagnosis: Barium swallow provides information regarding its size, location and character of the mucosal lining. Endoscopy reveal fibrosis and pooling of food in the diverticulum. Treatment: Excision of the pouch and cricopharyngeal myotomy done through cervical approach. Dohlman’s procedure: Partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by diathermy through a weerda scope. Endoscopic laser treatment: Partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by CO2 laser using endoscope. This procedure is known to have fewer recurrences and faster improvement in symptoms. Achalasia (OptionA): Lower esophageal sphincter fails to relax properly, leading to dysphagia for both solids and liquids. However, it typically does not cause halitosis or gurgling sound in the neck. Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) (Option B): Characterized by the reflux of stomach contents into the esophagus leading to heartburn, regurgitation, dysphagia. However, GERD usually does not present with bad breath, or gurgling sound in the neck. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome (Option D): Characterized by dysphagia, iron-deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs. While it involves dysphagia, it does not typically cause regurgitation of undigested food, bad breath or gurgling sound in the neck.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the parapharyngeal space is/are correct? 1) The parapharyngeal space extends from the base of the skull to the tracheal bifurcation. 2) The retropharyngeal space communicates with the parapharyngeal space. 3) The anterior compartment of the parapharyngeal space is related to the medial pterygoid muscle. 4) The posterior compartment of the parapharyngeal space contains the carotid artery, jugular vein, and cranial nerves IX, X, XI, XII.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 2,3,4 Explanation: Parapharyngeal space: Pyramidal, with its base at the skull's base and its apex at the hyoid bone. (Statement 1) Communications: retropharyngeal space (Statement 2) , submandibular, parotid, carotid, and visceral spaces. Relations of the Parapharyngeal Space: Medial: Buccopharyngeal fascia covering the constrictor muscles Posterior: Prevertebral fascia covering prevertebral muscles and transverse processes of cervical vertebrae Lateral: Medial pterygoid muscle, mandible, and deep surface of the parotid gland The styloid process and its attached muscles divide the parapharyngeal space into two compartments: Anterior compartment: Related to the tonsillar fossa (medially) and medial pterygoid muscle (laterally). (Statement 3) Posterior compartment: Related to the posterior part of the lateral pharyngeal wall (medially) and the parotid gland (laterally). Structures: Carotid artery, jugular vein, cranial nerves IX, X, XI, XII, and the sympathetic trunk , along with upper deep cervical nodes. (Statement 4) Retropharyngeal and Prevertebral spaces: Space Location Features Retro- pharyngeal Space Behind the pharynx Extent: from the skull base to tracheal bifurcation. (Statement 1) Infection may spread to the mediastinum. Divided into spaces of Gillette by median raphe. Pre- vertebral Space Between vertebral bodies (posterior) and prevertebral fascia (anterior) Extent: from the skull base to coccyx Infections often from vertebral caries. Abscess causes a midline bulge.

questions.question: Adult male with complaints of fever, throat pain on left side, painful swallowing with change in voice since 2 days. Oral examination revealed the following. No visible neck swelling is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Quinsy Explanation: Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Peritonsillar abscess , also known as Quinsy . Peritonsillar abscess (Quinsy): Definition Collection of pus in the peritonsillar space (between tonsil capsule and superior constrictor muscle). Aetiology Follows acute tonsillitis or can arise de novo. Infection begins in the tonsillar crypt Cause Streptococcus pyogenes, S. aureus, anaerobes or mixed

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with difficulty swallowing, a bulge in the pharynx behind the posterior pillar, and swelling in the parotid region. He also exhibits paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X, XI, and XII. What is the diagnosis?

options.A: Parapharyngeal abscess in the anterior compartment
options.B: Parapharyngeal abscess in the posterior compartment
options.C: Parapharyngeal abscess in the medial compartment
options.D: Parapharyngeal abscess in the lateral compartment

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Parapharyngeal abscess in the posterior compartment Explanation: Bulge of pharynx behind posterior pillar, paralysis of CN IX, X, XI, XII, and parotid region swelling are seen in the abscess of the posterior compartment of parapharyngeal space. Parapharyngeal abscess: Parapharyngeal Space Pyramidal in shape Base: skull Apex: hyoid bone Medial: buccopharyngeal fascia Posterior: prevertebral fascia Lateral: medial pterygoid muscle, mandible, deep surface of parotid gland Aetiology of Infection Pharynx: Acute/chronic infections (tonsil, adenoid), peritonsillar abscess Dental infections: usually lower last molars Ear: Bezold abscess, petrositis Infections of other spaces: Parotid, retropharyngeal, and submaxillary spaces External trauma Symptoms Fever Odynophagia Sore throat Torticollis Signs of toxaemia Compartment-wise symptoms Anterior compartment-anterior to styloid process. Abscess here causes: Prolapse of tonsil and tonsillar fossa Trismus External swelling behind angle of jaw Posterior compartment -posterior to styloid process. Abscess here causes: Bulge of pharynx behind posterior pillar Paralysis of CN IX, X, XI, XII, and sympathetic chain Parotid region swelling Minimal trismus or tonsillar prolapse Treatment Systemic antibiotic Drainage of abscess Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition, Page 314-316

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents with a 5-day history of sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and neck pain. On examination, there is a unilateral bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall and neck stiffness with limited movement. A lateral neck X-ray reveals a widened prevertebral shadow. What is the etiology?

options.A: Penetrating injury to posterior pharyngeal wall
options.C: Spread of infection from retropharyngeal lymph node

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Penetrating injury to posterior pharyngeal wall Explanation: Given is a scenario of an adult with acute retropharyngeal abscess. The most common etiology of an adult with acute retropharyngeal abscess is a penetrating injury to the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical esophagus. Acute retropharyngeal abscess: Retropharyngeal space Location: Behind the pharynx, between the buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia. Extent: From the base of the skull to the bifurcation of the trachea. Divisions: Two lateral compartments (spaces of Gillette) divided by a fibrous raphe. Communication: with parapharyngeal space Aetiology Children under 3 years (common): suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes from infections in adenoids, nasopharynx, posterior nasal sinuses, or nasal cavity. Adults: penetrating injuries to the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical esophagus. Clinical Features Dysphagia Breathing difficulty Stridor Croupy cough Torticollis Unilateral bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall Diagnosis X-ray neck lateral view shows widened prevertebral shadow, sometimes even the presence of gas Contrast-enhanced CT scan reveals the extent of the abscess Treatment Incision and drainage Systemic antibiotics Tracheostomy if needed

questions.question: A 40-year-old male with a history of untreated tuberculosis presents with mild throat discomfort and difficulty in swallowing. Examination reveals a central fluctuant swelling in the posterior pharyngeal wall, and X-rays confirm caries of the cervical spine. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Prevertebral abscess Explanation: Prevertebral abscess , which is formed as a complication of cervical spine caries due to TB, presents as a fluctuant swelling in the posterior pharyngeal wall centrally. Prevertebral Abscess: Prevertebral space Extent: Base of skull to coccyx Location: Between vertebrae on one side and prevertebral muscles and the prevertebral fascia on the other Aetiology Tubercular in nature, caused by: Caries of the cervical spine (central abscess behind prevertebral fascia) Tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes (unilateral abscess behind buccopharyngeal fascia) Clinical Features Throat discomfort Mild dysphagia Fluctuant swelling in posterior pharyngeal wall, either centrally or on one side of midline Treatment Incision and drainage Antitubercular therapy Comparison between retropharyngeal and prevertebral abscesses: Retropharyngeal Prevertebral Location of the space Behind the pharynx, between the buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia, extending from the base of the skull to the bifurcation of the trachea. Between vertebrae on one side and prevertebral muscles and the prevertebral fascia on the other, extenting from the base of skull to coccyx Etiology Children under 3 years (common)-suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes Adults-penetrating injuries to the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical esophagus. Tubercular in nature, caused by: Caries of the cervical spine or tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes Clinical features Dysphagia Breathing difficulty Stridor Croupy cough Torticollis Unilateral bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall Throat discomfort Mild dysphagia Fluctuant swelling in posterior pharyngeal wall, either centrally or on one side of midline
